abstract.para: &rear; (Relax and Recover) is an administrator tool-set for creating disaster recovery images. The disaster recovery information can either be stored via the network or locally on hard disks, USB devices, DVD/CD-R, tape or similar. The backup data is stored on a network file system (NFS).
Keep in mind, &rear; needs to be configured and tested before any disaster happens. &rear; will not save you, if a disaster has already taken place.

warning.title: Extensive Testing Required
warning.para: It is essential, whenever you create a rescue CD, to always test the disaster recovery with an identical test machine. Only if this procedure works satisfactorily, your disaster recovery system is correctly and reliably set up.

warning.title: No Version Upgrade for the &rear; Package
warning.para: &suse; does not deliver any updates for the &rear; package. It cannot be guaranteed that an existing &rear; disaster recovery set-up will still work after the upgrade.
If you do a &rear; version upgrade on your own, carefully revalidate that your particular &rear; disaster recovery procedure still works.

sect1.title: Conceptual Overview
sect1.para: &sls; ships a disaster recovery system in two packages:

The package rear-SUSE is another method of a disaster recovery which incorporates &ay; to recreate your basic system. You should try and test both methods for your systems. Every IT infrastructure is different, in one case rear is enough, in other situations rear-SUSE is a better fit. Regardless of the method, both are used in the following way:

formalpara.title: Preparation
formalpara.para: Make a bootable CD and backup system and user data.

formalpara.title: Testing
formalpara.para: Test the recovery process thoroughly and the backup on the same hardware as your main system before any disaster happens.

formalpara.title: Recovery
formalpara.para: Boot from the rescue CD and restore your system from your backup.

sect1.para: To prepare the rescue media, the following steps are performed by &rear;:

listitem.para: Store disk layout (partitioning, filesystems, LVM, RAID, and boot loader).
Clone the system (Kernel drivers and modules, device driver configuration, network configuration, system software and tools).
Create bootable rescue CD with system configuration.

sect1.para: When a disaster occurred, the recovery process takes these actions:

listitem.para: Restore the disk layout (partitions, RAID configurations, LVM, file systems).

sect1.title: Preparing for the Worst Scenarios: Disaster Recovery Plans
sect1.para: Before the worst scenario happens, take actions to prepare with a disaster recovery plan. A disaster recovery plan is a document where all risks, infrastructure, and the budget is being collected. Maybe you have already some plan in place, but here is the general overview:

formalpara.title: Risk Analysis
formalpara.para: Conduct a solid risk analysis of your infrastructure. List all the possible threats and evaluate how serious they are. Determine how likely these threats are and prioritize them. It is recommended to use a simple categorization: probability and impact.

formalpara.title: Budget Planing
formalpara.para: The outcome of the analysis is an overview, which risks can be tolerated and which are critical for your business. Ask yourself, how can you minimize risks and how much will it cost. Depending on how big your company is, spend two to fifteen percent of the overall IT budget on disaster recovery.

formalpara.title: Disaster Recovery Plan Development
formalpara.para: Make checklists, test procedures, establish and assign priorities, and inventory your IT infrastructure. Define how to deal with a problem when some services in your infrastructure fail. emap: Very vague. Examples would help or a reference to a source on how to create an actual DR plan. Like redundant systems, failover clusters, raids, etc. toms 2011-11-04: Yes, that's true, but that's the task of the administrators. It is only there to indicate, there is some work to do, and not just 'relax'. :)

formalpara.title: Test
formalpara.para: After defining an elaborate plan, test it. Test it at least once a year. Use the same testing hardware as your main IT infrastructure.

sect1.title: Setting Up &rear;
sect1.para: &rear; supports some backup tools (Tivoli Storage Manager, QNetix Galaxy, Symantec NetBackup, HP DataProtector) and can output its rescue medium to a CD or PXE environment. The restore step is possible through NFS or CIFS and other network file systems. Find more information in the manpage of &rear; (man rear).

To use &rear; you need at least two identical systems: the main machine where your productive environment is stored and the test machine. Identical in this context means, for example, you can replace a network card with another one using the same Kernel driver. If a hardware component does not use the same driver, it is not considered identical by &rear;.
&rear; can be used in different scenarios. The following example uses a NFS server as backup storage:

procedure.title: Storing Your Backup on a NFS Server

step.para: Set up a NFS server with &yast; as described in Sharing File Systems with NFS from .

Adapt the configuration file(s). Depending on how many servers you want to recover, use /etc/rear/site.conf for site-wide settings and /etc/rear/local.conf for machine-local settings. The following example uses a /etc/rear/local.conf configuration file. Replace the NETFS_URL with your own values. Further options are listed in the Various Settings section of the documentation at .

sect1.para: To perform a disaster recovery on your test machine, proceed as follows:

procedure.title: Perform Disaster Recovery on Test Machine

step.para: Locate the recovery ISO image stored as /tmp/rear-HOSTNAME.iso and burn it on CD.
Boot your test machine with the recovery CD.
Enter rear at the boot prompt.
Log in as &rootuser; (no password needed).
Enter rear recover to start the recovery process. The recovery process installs and configures the machine and retrieves the backup data from your NFS server.

sect1.para: After this procedure, make sure the test machine is correctly set up and can serve as a replacement for your main machine. Test this procedure on a regular basis to ensure everything works as expected. Keep copies of the rescue CD iso, in case the media is damaged.

sect1.title: Using the &yast; &rear; Module
sect1.para: The &yast; &rear; module can be used to start with a base setup. &rear; saves the recovery image and data on a NFS backend or an USB stick. However, the &yast; &rear; module does not support recovery from a disaster. This needs some expertise and has to be done manually by the administrator.
To start with a base setup, proceed as follows:

step.para: Decide how to start your recovery system. Choose USB if you want to boot from an USB stick or ISO for CD-ROM respectively.
Decide where the backup should be stored. Either select NFS or USB:

listitem.para: Select NFS if you have to use a server that offers Network File System. Specify the location as nfs://hostname/directory.
Select USB, if you want to store your data on an USB stick. If no USB devices are shown, attach an USB stick or an USB disk and click Rescan USB Devices.

step.para: If you want a previous backup copy to be safed, check Keep old backup.
If you want to add additional directories that should also be included in your backup, use the Advanced menu and select Additional Directories in Backup.

In case your rescue system does not boot due to missing Kernel modules, use the Advanced menu, select Additional Kernel Modules in Rescue System, and add the respective Kernel modules into the list of added modules for your rescue system.
Click the Save and run rear now button to start the backup process.

sect1.para: After the &yast; &rear; module is finished with the backup, test your backup to make sure it works as expected.

sect1.title: Setting Up rear-SUSE with &ay;
sect1.para: With the package rear-SUSE, the recovery process uses &ay; together with a &rear; backup, which is stored on a NFS server. Before you use it, check your disk space, you need at least 5 GB and up to 15 GB. The size is the sum of the following:

listitem.para: The &suse; installation medium (size of 5 GB DVD)
A working directory copied from the &suse; installation medium. The working copy is used by rear-SUSE for preparing the recovery ISO image.
Recovery ISO image. From 500 MB up to 5 GB.

sect1.para: Depending on your situation, you can limit the overall size. Refer to the rear-SUSE documentation for details in /usr/share/doc/packages/rear-SUSE/README.

note.title: Support of File Systems
note.para: &ay; can only recover file systems which are supported by &yast;. Some file systems, like OCFS2, are currently not supported.

sect1.para: The following procedure creates a full recovery ISO image. This means, it downloads the &suse; installation medium, creates a full backup, and generates the recovery ISO image. Proceed as follows:

step.para:
Get the IP or hostname of your NFS server where your &rear; backup will be stored. If you do not have one, set up as described in Sharing File Systems with NFS
.
Proceed with the backup as described in , but use the command rear mkbackuponly to prepare the backup. You do not need to burn the CD.
Start the backup, and replace BASE_DIR with your working directory (for example, /var/tmp/rear-SUSE/), and MEDIUM_URI (for example, http://server/path/medium.iso):
step.screen: RecoveryImage -c configure-all -d BASE_DIR \ -l log-to-base-dir \ -b make-rear-backup \ -a clone-system \ -i install-RPMs \ -r restore-all \ -m MEDIUM_URI
step.para: This will start the backup process and store your data on your NFS server. After the backup process, the recovery ISO image is created.
Burn the recovery ISO image on a DVD. Find the image in your BASE_DIR path with the name RecoverImage.DATE.iso.

sect1.para: After the DVD has been burnt, test your disaster recovery with another server using the same hardware. For example, identical hardware is a hard disk with the same disk geometry, or a network card which uses the same Kernel driver.

step.para: Boot your test machine with the recovery image from of .
Enter autorecover at the boot prompt. The recovery image boots and starts the &ay; installation process.
Follow the instructions on the screen. Any error messages regarding the packages rear or rear-SUSE can be ignored.

sect1.para: After the recovery, make sure the test machine functions properly and all data has been restored correctly from your NFS backup.
